name: Magic lanterns and internet culture
description: The basic animation techniques of magic lanterns are strangely similar to internet aesthetics.

key_work.title: English mahogany and brass bi-unial magic lantern
key_work.brief_description: The magic lantern is an important ancestor of cinema. Developed in the 1600s, magic lanterns use a light source, lenses and transparent slides to project religious, educational or entertaining scenes and stories. Bi-unial lanterns use two lenses to create the illusion of movement.

constellations_primary.name: Magic lanterns and internet culture
constellations_primary.description: The basic animation techniques of magic lanterns are strangely similar to internet aesthetics.

start.title: If We Don't, Remember Me
start.brief_description:
IWDRM was a blog of animated movie stills active from 2010 to 2015.

A video installation was shown in exhibitions at the Contemporary Arts Museum (Houston, TX), &FOAM (Amsterdam) and The Event (Birmingham).

constellations_other.name: Magic lanterns and internet culture
constellations_other.description: The basic animation techniques of magic lanterns are strangely similar to internet aesthetics.

end.title: Unknown Game of Thrones reaction gif

constellations_other.name: Magic lanterns and internet culture
constellations_other.description: The basic animation techniques of magic lanterns are strangely similar to internet aesthetics.

links.description: However, many GIFs used across social media now recontextualise popular film and TV texts to reconfigure meaning, represent emotions and reactions, and find unlikely humour. Often these moments cross countries and cultures, with many reproduced in languages other than English.

start.title: Netscape Navigator 2 GIF
start.brief_description: Netscape Navigator 2 was a proprietary web browser released by Netscape Communications Corporation as its flagship product.

constellations_other.name: Magic lanterns and internet culture
constellations_other.description: The basic animation techniques of magic lanterns are strangely similar to internet aesthetics.

end.title: My Boyfriend Came Back from the War
end.brief_description: My Boyfriend Came Back From the War is a browser-based internet artwork created in 1996 by Russian artist Olia Lialina and is an example of interactive hypertext storytelling.

constellations_other.name: Magic lanterns and internet culture
constellations_other.description: The basic animation techniques of magic lanterns are strangely similar to internet aesthetics.

links.description: When the GIF patent expired in 1998, the format was open to the public domain, where it was adopted by artists like Olia Lialina, whose first GIF was an eerie monochrome window and part of her browser-based artwork My Boyfriend Came Back from the War.

start.title: My Boyfriend Came Back from the War
start.brief_description: My Boyfriend Came Back From the War is a browser-based internet artwork created in 1996 by Russian artist Olia Lialina and is an example of interactive hypertext storytelling.

constellations_other.name: Magic lanterns and internet culture
constellations_other.description: The basic animation techniques of magic lanterns are strangely similar to internet aesthetics.

end.title: If We Don't, Remember Me
end.brief_description:
IWDRM was a blog of animated movie stills active from 2010 to 2015.

A video installation was shown in exhibitions at the Contemporary Arts Museum (Houston, TX), &FOAM (Amsterdam) and The Event (Birmingham).

constellations_other.name: Magic lanterns and internet culture
constellations_other.description: The basic animation techniques of magic lanterns are strangely similar to internet aesthetics.

links.description: GIFs aren’t only made by artists, but also to highlight artistry. Cinephiles make GIFs called cinemagraphs, which frame film scenes like paintings, popular on Tumblr sites like ‘If we don’t, remember me’.

end.title: Game of Thrones
end.creator_credit: Christopher Newman, Duncan Muggoch, Greg Spence, Lisa McAtackney, Devin Stoutley, Paul Zeke and Shaila Tobin

video_links.name: Game of Thrones | Season 1 | Official Trailer

end.brief_description: Seven noble families fight for control of the mythical land of Westeros. Friction between the houses leads to full-scale war. All while a very ancient evil awakens in the farthest north. Amidst the war, a neglected military order of misfits, the Night’s Watch, is all that stands between the realms of men and icy horrors beyond.

constellations_other.name: Infinity and beyond
constellations_other.description: The constantly evolving characters in Infinity are created through procedural generation, a technique that creates special effects, characters, videogame levels and sound via a set of algorithms, predefined rules or data inputs.

constellations_other.name: The Hatfield House rules
constellations_other.description: The shooting location of The Favourite, Hatfield House, has appeared in a number of other iconic works.

constellations_other.name: The narrative power of maps
constellations_other.description: Maps are designed to communicate complex information in a clear manner to aid both navigation and wayfinding and knowledge of place.

constellations_other.name: Significant sounds
constellations_other.description: The arrival of synchronised sound dramatically changed the movie business, allowing filmmakers to use sound in new and exciting ways which developed the use sound into own film language.

constellations_other.name: Magic lanterns and internet culture
constellations_other.description: The basic animation techniques of magic lanterns are strangely similar to internet aesthetics.

links.description: One of the most used texts for reactions is HBO’s Game of Thrones, a cultural phenomenon that ran for eight seasons and was lauded for its revisionist fantasy narrative… until it wasn’t.

end.title: All men must die, but we are not men
end.brief_description:
Xanthe Dobbie is a queer new media artist in Sydney + Melbourne.

xanthedobbie.com

constellations_other.name: Magic lanterns and internet culture
constellations_other.description: The basic animation techniques of magic lanterns are strangely similar to internet aesthetics.

links.description: Artist Xanthe Dobbie repurposes heroines from cult shows like Game of Thrones, infusing still photos with symbolic GIFs that channel early internet aesthetics to recontextualise pop culture history through a playful, feminist lens.

start.title: English mahogany and brass bi-unial magic lantern
start.brief_description: The magic lantern is an important ancestor of cinema. Developed in the 1600s, magic lanterns use a light source, lenses and transparent slides to project religious, educational or entertaining scenes and stories. Bi-unial lanterns use two lenses to create the illusion of movement.

constellations_primary.name: Magic lanterns and internet culture
constellations_primary.description: The basic animation techniques of magic lanterns are strangely similar to internet aesthetics.

end.title: Netscape Navigator 2 GIF
end.brief_description: Netscape Navigator 2 was a proprietary web browser released by Netscape Communications Corporation as its flagship product.

constellations_other.name: Magic lanterns and internet culture
constellations_other.description: The basic animation techniques of magic lanterns are strangely similar to internet aesthetics.

links.description: Biunial magic lanterns projected different images through two lenses in a repetitive loop to suggest movement, much like GIFs, which use timed delays to loop images in a web browser and were first supported on Netscape Navigator 2.
